item.title: New Covid variant: Javid says UK must act quickly over public health risk
item.description: The health secretary says southern African travel restrictions were imposed due to a "substantial risk" to health.

item.title: Channel migrants: Emmanuel Macron and Boris Johnson clash over crisis
item.description: The French president accuses the UK prime minister of not being serious as diplomatic row escalates.

item.title: Ava White: Liverpool murder arrests after girl, 12, dies
item.description: Four boys, aged between 13 and 15, are arrested on suspicion of murdering Ava White in Liverpool.

item.title: Storm Arwen: Red wind warning for parts of UK
item.description: The red alert - the highest level, meaning lives could be at risk - comes in from 15:00 GMT.

item.title: Black Friday tipped to hit strongest ever sales
item.description: Analysts say this year's sale will be the biggest ever, but retailers won't offer as many discounts.

item.title: Bobbi-Anne McLeod: Man in court charged with murder
item.description: Cody Ackland, 24, from Plymouth, appeared in court charged with the murder of the 18-year-old.

item.title: Southampton FC left coach 'free' to abuse boys
item.description: A report finds Southampton Football Club "failed to put the safety and welfare of boys first".

item.title: UK car output suffers worst October for 65 years
item.description: Chip shortages lead to production dropping to the lowest level recorded for October since 1956.

item.title: Gracie Spinks: Officers face misconduct probe after woman's death
item.description: A stalking complaint was made and a bag of weapons was discovered before Gracie Spinks died.

item.title: Extinction Rebellion activists target UK Amazon distribution centres
item.description: Extinction Rebellion has targeted 15 sites in the UK on the retail giant's busiest day of the year.

item.title: Motsi Mabuse to miss Strictly Come Dancing after Covid contact
item.description: The judge will be replaced by Cynthia Erivo this weekend after being contacted by NHS Test and Trace.

item.title: Quiz of the week: Why did Boris Johnson like Peppa Pig World so much?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: Mobile phone museum celebrates ugly and iconic phones
item.description: A new museum showcasing more than 2,000 retro mobile phones launches online.

item.title: Commons Speaker ruffles Boris' feathers on Newscast
item.description: Sir Lindsay Hoyle brought his pet parrot Boris to a BBC Newscast interview and the bird took off.

item.title: Nile Rodgers is auctioning guitars for talented teenagers
item.description: The music producer and guitarist hopes to raise money to help talented teenagers.

item.title: Browns of Chester: How a city is coping without Debenhams
item.description: Browns of Chester served the city for 241 years before it closed when the chain collapsed in May.

item.title: Dramatic rescue of 300 from migrant boat in Italy
item.description: Some people were already in the water when the Italian coastguard reached them off Lampedusa Island.

item.title: Egypt: Grand opening for Luxor's 'Avenue of the Sphinxes'
item.description: The ancient walkway, connecting two of the Egyptian city's greatest temples, took decades to excavate.

item.title: Black Friday: 'Harder to give big, headline discounts'
item.description: Steve Finch of toy retailer bopster, explains the pressures his firm is under for Black Friday this year.

item.title: New Covid variant: Pride and punishment follows South Africa discovery
item.description: South Africans feel they are paying the price for their ability to monitor new Covid variants.

item.title: The ‘cocaine collectors’ retrieving smuggled drugs in Rotterdam
item.description: Young criminals are risking their lives to retrieve drugs smuggled into the Netherlands amongst freight arriving from Latin America.

item.title: Cambridge sculpture makes a stand on culture wars
item.description: Leading academics see Paulo Freire as a symbol of "tolerance and dialogue" amid tensions on campuses.

item.title: Ghosn affair: The forgotten man in the Nissan scandal
item.description: Wife of a former Nissan boss on trial in Japan says he is a forgotten victim of the Carlos Ghosn affair.

item.title: Upcoming Moon missions spur the search for new spacesuits
item.description: Nasa has asked the private sector to design new spacesuits that can be used on the Moon.

item.title: Rahul Dravid: Indian cricket's unassuming maestro
item.description: The return of Indian cricket's golden boy as coach will start a new era, writes columnist Ayaz Memon.

item.title: New Zealand fight back against India in first Test
item.description: Seamer Tim Southee took 5-69 and openers Will Young and Tom Latham hit unbeaten half-centuries as New Zealand fought back on day two of the first Test against India in Kanpur.

item.title: NFL Thanksgiving: Umpire trips as Tony Pollard runs in 100-yard touchdown for Dallas Cowboys
item.description: Tony Pollard runs in a tremendous 100-yard touchdown while the umpire trips on the sidelines in the Dallas Cowboys' 36-33 loss to the Las Vegas Raiders.

item.title: 'One of the greatest thinkers in football' - what can Man Utd expect from Rangnick?
item.description: Manchester United are close to appointing Ralf Rangnick as interim manager, but what will the German bring to Old Trafford?

item.title: Ole Gunnar Solskjaer: Marcus Rashford says sacked Manchester United boss 'deserves huge respect'
item.description: Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford says the club's players still respect former boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, who was sacked from his job at Old Trafford last weekend.

item.title: What are the Covid variants and will vaccines still work?
item.description: A new version of Covid looks different to the virus vaccines were designed to fight.

item.title: The African countries on the red list - and other UK travel rules
item.description: There are new restrictions on travellers returning from several southern African countries.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms of coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: People in England are being advised to test for Covid before going to crowded places this winter.

item.title: New Covid variant: Where do variants come from?
item.description: New Covid-19 variants keep appearing – and their mutations are very different to the comic book kind.

item.title: Covid: Who can have a booster jab and how can you get one?
item.description: All over-40s will be offered a booster vaccination, and pregnant women are urged to get jabbed.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: Like Scotland and Wales, Northern Ireland will introduce a vaccine passport for entry to large events.

item.title: Are we heading for a UK lockdown?
item.description: As soaring cases lead European countries to reintroduce Covid restrictions, what does it mean for the UK?

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: Northern Ireland ministers have urged people to keep working from home wherever possible.

item.title: Covid: When can teenagers get a second dose?
item.description: All 16 and 17 year-olds in the UK can now have a second dose 12 weeks after the first.

item.title: Can I get a free flu jab?
item.description: Health officials are urging millions of people to get a free flu vaccination this winter.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: How many people are vaccinated so far?
item.description: A look at the progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as more than 50 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Face coverings could become a legal requirement in England again if the NHS struggles this winter.

item.title: Channel tragedy: Scramble to identify dead off Calais
item.description: At least 27 people died trying to reach the UK by boat. Officials are trying to find their identities.

item.title: Why do migrants leave France and try to cross the English Channel?
item.description: Rising numbers of migrants are trying to cross the English Channel in small boats.

item.title: Channel migrants: Why politics is dominating the debate on migrants
item.description: UK-French rivalry is making a common solution difficult, says the BBC's Europe Editor Katya Adler.

item.title: Channel deaths: What do we know so far?
item.description: There are many unanswered questions following the deaths of 27 people. Here is what we know so far.

item.title: Why Iraqi Kurds risk their lives to reach the West
item.description: What drives people to make the perilous journey, which for many has ended in death?

item.title: Channel migrants: What happens to people crossing to the UK?
item.description: Record numbers of migrants have been crossing the English Channel in boats in recent months.

item.title: CEO Secrets: From Ordsall poverty to being a billionaire
item.description: Peter Done, co-founder of Betfred and CEO of Peninsula, shares his business advice for CEO Secrets.

item.title: New mothers who died of herpes could have been infected by one surgeon
item.description: Two mothers who died of herpes after ​having Caesareans could have been infected by a single surgeon, the BBC has found.

item.title: Evil Corp: 'My hunt for the world's most wanted hackers'
item.description: The BBC’s Joe Tidy goes to Russia in search of men on the FBI’s cyber most wanted list.
